misconceptions.name: Implemented a different program instead of the required number guessing game
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a road trip cost calculator rather than the specified number guessing game. None of the required behaviors (random answer, repeated guesses, high/low hints, termination on correct guess) are present, indicating a misunderstanding or misreading of the problem requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that writing a program to compute the cost of a road trip (using distance, MPG, and price per gallon) is an acceptable answer to this question.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should implement a number guessing game: generate a random integer between 1 and 100, repeatedly prompt the user to guess, print "Too high" or "Too low" after incorrect guesses, and stop only when the correct guess is made, reporting how many guesses were taken.
symptoms: Program prompts for driving distance, miles per gallon, and price per gallon instead of guesses.
No use of Random or generation of a secret number between 1 and 100.
No loop for repeated guessing.
No conditional logic for "Too high" or "Too low" hints.
Program terminates after computing and printing a driving cost.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely misreading the assignment prompt or reusing code from a different exercise (cost of driving) without adapting it to the current problem requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully re-read the problem statement and sample run. Before coding, list the required inputs, outputs, and steps (random number generation, loop, comparisons, hints, and termination condition). Then write code that directly follows that plan.
related_concepts: Mapping requirements to input/output and control flow
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program structure and prompts clearly correspond to a different textbook-style problem (road trip cost) and contain none of the elements of a number guessing game.

evidence.note: This code calculates driving cost instead of implementing a number guessing game with random number generation, looping guesses, and high/low hints.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect Program Implementation
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program for calculating the cost of a road trip (based on the class name `RoadTripCost` and the logic used) instead of implementing the required Number Guessing Game. This demonstrates a complete misunderstanding or misreading of the problem requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student seems to believe that they can submit code for a different, unrelated assignment and it will satisfy the requirements for the Number Guessing Game.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The student must write a program that features a random number generator, a guessing loop, and conditional feedback ('Too high'/'Too low').
symptoms: The file name and code logic correspond to a 'Road Trip Cost' calculator.
None of the required elements of the Number Guessing Game (Random number generation, loop, comparison, etc.) are present.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misinterpreting the problem requirements or submitting the wrong file/solution for the assignment.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully read the assignment prompt (Q2. Number Guessing Game) and implement the specified logic, including random number generation, user input inside a loop, and conditional feedback.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code is entirely unrelated to the requested task (Number Guessing Game). It does not contain any of the required elements.

evidence.note: The class name indicates an implementation of an entirely different problem.
The core logic calculates cost based on distance, mpg, and price, entirely failing to address any part of the number guessing game requirements.

misconceptions.name: Complete misunderstanding of assignment requirements
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code for an entirely different program (road trip cost calculator) instead of the number guessing game requested in Q2.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they are solving a problem about calculating road trip costs based on distance, miles per gallon, and fuel price.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Q2 requires implementing a number guessing game where the computer picks a random number between 1-100 and the user guesses repeatedly with feedback on whether their guess is too high or too low.
symptoms: No random number generation for a guessing game
No loop structure for repeated guessing attempts
No conditional logic for 'Too high' or 'Too low' feedback
Program calculates fuel costs instead of playing a guessing game
No guess counter or termination condition for correct guesses
misconceptions.root_cause: Fundamental misreading or misunderstanding of the assignment question. The student may have submitted code from a different question or assignment.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read Q2 carefully. The task requires: (1) generating a random number 1-100, (2) a loop for user guesses, (3) comparison logic with feedback, and (4) a counter to track guesses. Start by setting up the Random object and reading the first guess.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: This is unambiguous - the submitted code implements an entirely different program. There is no overlap with the guessing game requirements whatsoever.

evidence.note: The entire submission is a road trip cost calculator program, not a number guessing game. No elements of Q2 (random numbers, guessing loop, high/low feedback) are present.

misconceptions.name: Solved the wrong problem (road trip cost instead of number guessing game)
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute the cost of a road trip rather than a number guessing game where the computer picks a random number between 1 and 100 and the user repeatedly guesses until correct with "Too high" / "Too low" hints.
misconceptions.student_belief: I believe that for this question, I should write a program that reads driving distance, miles per gallon, and gas price, then computes and prints the cost of driving.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this question, the program should implement a number guessing game: generate a random integer between 1 and 100, repeatedly prompt the user to guess until the correct number is guessed, give "Too high" or "Too low" hints after each incorrect guess, and report how many guesses were taken.
symptoms: Program asks for driving distance, miles per gallon, and price per gallon instead of a guess between 1 and 100.
No use of Random or any random number generation.
No loop that allows multiple guesses until correct.
No conditional logic that prints "Too high" or "Too low".
Output describes cost of driving instead of correctness of guesses.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misinterpretation of the problem requirements or reuse of code from a different assignment, leading to implementing a completely different task than the specified number guessing game.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and discard the road-trip-cost logic. Start a new program that (1) creates a Random object and generates an int between 1 and 100, (2) uses a loop to repeatedly ask the user for a guess, (3) compares the guess to the secret number to print "Too high" or "Too low", and (4) stops only when the guess is correct and then reports how many guesses were taken.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program structure and all prompts/variables relate to computing driving cost, with no elements of a number guessing game; this strongly indicates the student implemented the wrong problem.

evidence.note: The code is a cost-of-driving calculator with no random number, guessing loop, or high/low hints, indicating the student implemented a different problem than the required number guessing game.

misconceptions.name: Complete Misinterpretation of Assignment Requirements
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program fulfilling the requirements of an unrelated task (calculating road trip cost) instead of the assigned 'Number Guessing Game'. The core mechanics of the required game (random number generation, iteration, comparison logic) are entirely absent.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have submitted code for a completely different assignment or misunderstood which program file was required for this question.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task required implementing a Number Guessing Game involving generating a random number, setting up a guess loop, and providing high/low feedback until the correct number is found.
symptoms: The code asks for 'distance', 'mpg', and 'pricePerGallon'
The code performs a cost calculation formula
No use of Random class or number generation related to the game
No looping structure for repeated guesses
misconceptions.root_cause: Submission error, or complete failure to read and address the prompt for Q2.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the assignment prompt (Q2) and implement the logic for the Number Guessing Game. Start by ensuring the secret number is generated randomly between 1 and 100.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: High confidence, as the submitted code explicitly solves a different problem (Road Trip Cost calculation) and contains none of the elements required for the Number Guessing Game (Q2).

evidence.note: The class name suggests the code is unrelated to the assignment Q2.
Input prompts and variable names clearly indicate a cost calculation program, not a guessing game.

misconceptions.name: Fundamental problem misunderstanding
misconceptions.description: Student submitted code for an entirely different problem (road trip cost calculator) instead of a number guessing game. This indicates a critical failure to understand or read the assignment specification.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have either submitted the wrong file, misread the assignment, or confused Q2 with a different problem from the course.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Q2 requires implementing a number guessing game with random number generation, a loop for multiple guesses, conditional logic for feedback, and a termination condition for correct guesses.
symptoms: Submitted program has completely different logic (calculates road trip costs)
No randomness involved
No loop structure
No comparative feedback mechanism
Program terminates immediately after single calculation
misconceptions.root_cause: Student failed to read assignment requirements carefully or submitted code from a different problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read Q2 requirements carefully. Start from scratch with: (1) Random number generation, (2) do-while or while loop, (3) Scanner input for guesses, (4) if-else logic for feedback, (5) counter for guess attempts.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Complete mismatch between assignment specification and submission code is unambiguous. The submitted program addresses zero of the five required components.

evidence.note: This entire program implements road trip cost calculation, not the number guessing game specified in Q2.
